title: Diabetes and Hallucinations
author: Barbara Brody

content: If you have type 2 diabetes , it's important to keep your blood sugar in check. Along with checking your sugar levels regularly, you should be aware of the signs that it may be running high. High blood sugar may cause you to feel thirsty, tired, or nauseated.
If it gets extremely high, you might have hallucinations. You need medical help right away if your blood sugar is very high.

sections.heading: Hyperosmolar Hyperglycemic Syndrome
content: If your blood sugar is higher than 600 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL), you have a condition called diabetic hyperosmolar hyperglycemic syndrome. In an effort to cope with too much sugar in your bloodstream, your body releases it into your urine and takes lots of fluids away along with it. You need treatment quickly to get hydrated so you don't get seriously dehydrated. At worst, you could end up in a coma or even die.

Hallucinations -- when you see and or hear things that aren't there -- are one sign of this syndrome. When you're very dehydrated, the balance of essential minerals in your body (called electrolytes) gets out of whack. That can affect the communication between your brain cells and lead to hallucinations. Once your doctor is able to rehydrate you and lower your blood sugar, the hallucinations will end.

content: If you have hyperosmolar hyperglycemic syndrome, you might also:

Although hyperosmolar hyperglycemic syndrome isn’t common, anyone with any kind of diabetes can get it. But people with type 2 diabetes are most likely to. The risk is highest for those with type 2 who also:
bullets: Feel weak or be unable to move parts of your body
Are African American, Native American, or Hispanic
Have another health issue (like a heart condition)

sections.heading: Treatment and Prevention
content: If you have hyperosmolar hyperglycemic syndrome, hospital doctors will treat you with:

The best way to prevent hyperosmolar hyperglycemic syndrome is to keep your blood sugar under control. To do that, keep track of your blood sugar and follow your doctor's recommendations for treatment and a healthy lifestyle.
bullets: Electrolytes to replace those lost due to dehydration
Insulin to bring your blood sugar down

sections.heading: Helping Someone Who Is Hallucinating
content: A person who is having hallucinations may see, hear, or feel things that aren't there. The hallucinations can seem very real. This can very be upsetting to them.

If you're with someone you suspect may have hyperosmolar hyperglycemic syndrome, call 911 right away. Try to stay calm and comfort them. If possible, the affected person should drink a lot of water while waiting for help.

meta_description: If you have diabetes and your blood sugar gets very high, you can have hallucinations. They're one sign of a serious condition called diabetic hyperosmolar hyperglycemic syndrome. Learn more about what can cause them.
